text: Window, very small in the distance, illuminated. All around this is an almost totally black screen.  Now, the camera moves slowly towards the window which is almos postage stamp in the frame, other forms appear; barbed wi cyclone fencing, and now, looming up against an early mor sky, enormous iron grille work.  Camera travels up what i shown to be a gateway of gigantic proportions and holds o top of it - a huge initial "K" showing darker and darker the dawn sky.  Through this and beyond we see the fairy-t mountaintop of Xanadu, the great castle a sillhouette as summit, the little window a distant accent in the darknes

The literally incredible domain of CHARLES FOSTER KANE. Its right flank resting for nearly forty miles on the Gul Coast, it truly extends in all directions farther than th can see.  Designed by nature to be almost completely bare flat - it was, as will develop, practically all marshland Kane acquired and changed its face - it is now pleasantly uneven, with its fair share of rolling hills and one very sized mountain, all man-made.  Almost all the land is imp either through cultivation for farming purposes of throug careful landscaping, in the shape of parks and lakes.  Th castle dominates itself, an enormous pile, compounded of genuine castles, of European origin, of varying architect dominates the scene, from the very peak of the mountain.
Past which we move.  The greens are straggly and overgrow the fairways wild with tropical weeds, the links unused a not seriously tended for a long time.

head_text.subj: WHAT WAS ONCE A GOOD-SIZED ZOO, (MINIATURE)

text: Of the Hagenbeck type.  All that now remains, with one  exception, are the individual plots, surrounded by moats, which the animals are kept, free and yet safe from each o and the landscape at large.  (Signs on several of the plo indicate that here there were once tigers, lions, girrafe

In the foreground, a great obscene ape is outlined agains dawn murk.  He is scratching himself slowly, thoughtfully looking out across the estates of Charles Foster Kane, to distant light glowing in the castle on the hill.
The idiot pile of sleepy dragons.  Reflected in the muddy the lighted window.

The boat landing sags.  An old newspaper floats on the su of the water - a copy of the New York Enquirer."  As it m across the frame, it discloses again the reflection of th window in the castle, closer than before.
It is empty.  A newspaper blows across the cracked floor the tank.
In the shadows, literally the shadows, of the castle.  As move by, we see that their doors and windows are boarded and locked, with heavy bars as further protection and sea

Over a wide moat, now stagnant and choked with weeds.  We across it and through a huge solid gateway into a formal perhaps thirty yards wide and one hundred yards deep, whi extends right up to the very wall of the castle.  The  landscaping surrounding it has been sloppy and causal for long time, but this particular garden has been kept up in perfect shape.  As the camera makes its way through it, t the lighted window of the castle, there are revealed rare exotic blooms of all kinds.  The dominating note is one o almost exaggerated tropical lushness, hanging limp and  despairing.  Moss, moss, moss.  Ankor Wat, the night the King died.

Camera moves in until the frame of the window fills the f of the screen.  Suddenly, the light within goes out.  Thi stops the action of the camera and cuts the music which h been accompanying the sequence.  In the glass panes of th window, we see reflected the ripe, dreary landscape of Mr Kane's estate behind and the dawn sky.
A very long shot of Kane's enormous bed, silhouetted agai the enormous window.

An incredible one.  Big, impossible flakes of snow, a too picturesque farmhouse and a snow man.  The jingling of sl bells in the musical score now makes an ironic reference Indian Temple bells - the music freezes -
Rosebud...

The camera pulls back, showing the whole scene to be cont in one of those glass balls which are sold in novelty sto all over the world.  A hand - Kane's hand, which has been holding the ball, relaxes.  The ball falls out of his han bounds down two carpeted steps leading to the bed, the ca following.  The ball falls off the last step onto the mar floor where it breaks, the fragments glittering in the fi rays of the morning sun.  This ray cuts an angular patter across the floor, suddenly crossed with a thousand bars o light as the blinds are pulled across the window. The foot of Kane's bed.  The camera very close.  Outlined against the shuttered window, we can see a form - the for a nurse, as she pulls the sheet up over his head.  The ca follows this action up the length of the bed and arrives the face after the sheet has covered it.

NOTE:  Here follows a typical news digest short, one of t regular monthly or bi-monthly features, based on public e or personalities.  These are distinguished from ordinary  newsreels and short subjects in that they have a fully de editorial or storyline.  Some of the more obvious  characteristics of the "March of Time," for example, as w as other documentary shorts, will be combined to give an  authentic impression of this now familiar type of short s As is the accepted procedure in these short subjects, a n is used as well as explanatory titles.
Legendary was the Xanadu where  Kubla Kahn decreed his stately  pleasure dome - (with quotes in his  voice) "Where twice five miles of fertile  ground, with walls and towers were  girdled 'round."

Today, almost as legendary is  Florida's XANADU - world's largest  private pleasure ground.  Here, on  the deserts of the Gulf Coast, a  private mountain was commissioned,  successfully built for its landlord.   Here in a private valley, as in  the Coleridge poem, "blossoms many  an incense-bearing tree."  Verily,  "a miracle of rare device."
Opening shot of great desolate expanse of Florida coastli (1940 - DAY)
Series of shots showing various aspects of Xanadu, all as might be photographed by an ordinary newsreel cameraman - photographed, but not atmospheric to the extreme extent o Prologue (1940).

(dropping the quotes) Here, for Xanadu's landlord, will  be held 1940's biggest, strangest  funeral; here this week is laid to  rest a potent figure of our Century -  America's Kubla Kahn - Charles  Foster Kane.  In journalism's  history, other names are honored  more than Charles Foster Kane's,  more justly revered.  Among  publishers, second only to James  Gordon Bennet the First: his  dashing, expatriate son; England's  Northcliffe and Beaverbrook;  Chicago's Patterson and McCormick;

text: Shot of a huge, screen-filling picture of Kane.  Pull bac show that it is a picture on the front page of the "Enqui surrounded by the reversed rules of mourning, with masthe and headlines. (1940)

A great number of headlines, set in different types and  different styles, obviously from different papers, all  announcing Kane's death, all appearing over photographs o Kane himself (perhaps a fifth of the headlines are in for languages).  An important item in connection with the hea is that many of them - positively not all - reveal passio conflicting opinions about Kane.  Thus, they contain vari the words "patriot," "democrat," "pacifist," "war-monger, "traitor," "idealist," "American," etc.

Newsreel shots of San Francisco during and after the fire followed by shots of special trains with large streamers: Relief Organization."  Over these shots superimpose the d 1906. Artist's painting of Foch's railroad car and peace negoti if actual newsreel shot unavailable.  Over this shot  sumperimpose the date - 1918.

Denver's Bonfils and Sommes; New  York's late, great Joseph Pulitzer;  America's emperor of the news  syndicate, another editorialist  and landlord, the still mighty and  once mightier Hearst.  Great names  all of them - but none of them so loved, hated, feared, so often  spoken - as Charles Foster Kane. The San Francisco earthquake.   First with the news were the Kane  papers.  First with Relief of the  Sufferers, First with the news of  their Relief of the Sufferers. Kane papers scoop the world on the  Armistice - publish, eight hours  before competitors, complete details  of the Armistice teams granted the  Germans by Marshall Foch from his  railroad car in the Forest of  Compeigne.  For forty years appeared  in Kane newsprint no public issue  on which Kane papers took no stand. No public man whom Kane himself  did not support or denounce - often  support, then denounce.  Its humble  beginnings, a dying dailey -

Brief clips of old newreel shots of William Jennings Brya Theodore Roosevelt, Stalin, Walter P. Thatcher, Al Smith, McKinley, Landon, Franklin D. Roosevelt and such.  Also, newsreels of the elderly Kane with such Nazis as Hitler a Goering; and England's Chamberlain and Churchill. Shot of a ramshackle building with old-fashioned presses through plate glass windows and the name "Enquirer" in ol fashioned gold letters. (1892)

Kane's empire, in its glory, held  dominion over thirty-seven  newpapers, thirteen magazines, a  radio network.  An empire upon an  empire.  The first of grocery  stores, paper mills, apartment  buildings, factories, forests, ocean-liners - An empire through  which for fifty years flowed, in  an unending stream, the wealth of  the earth's third richest gold  mine...  Famed in American legend  is the origin of the Kane fortune...   How, to boarding housekeeper Mary  Kane, by a defaulting boarder, in  1868 was left the supposedly  worthless deed to an abandoned  mine shaft: The Colorado Lode. The magnificent Enquirer Building  of today.

1891-1911 - a map of the USA, covering the entire screen, in animated diagram shows the Kane publications spreading city to city.  Starting from New York, minature newboys s madly to Chicago, Detroit, St. Louis, Los Angeles, San  Francisco, Washington, Atlanta, El Paso, etc., screaming  "Wuxtry, Kane Papers, Wuxtry." Shot of a large mine going full blast, chimneys belching trains moving in and out, etc.  A large sign reads "Color Lode Mining Co." (1940)  Sign reading; "Little Salem, CO

An old still shot of Little Salem as it was 70 years ago  (identified by copper-plate caption beneath the still). ( Shot of early tintype stills of Thomas Foster Kane and hi wife, Mary, on their wedding day.  A similar picture of M Kane some four or five years later with her little boy, C Foster Kane.

Fifty-seven years later, before a  Congressional Investigation, Walter  P.  Thatcher, grand old man of  Wall Street, for years chief target  of Kane papers' attack on "trusts,"  recalls a journey he made as a  youth...

Shot of Capitol, in Washington D.C. Shot of Congressional Investigating Committee (reproducti existing J.P. Morgan newsreel).  This runs silent under  narration.  Walter P. Thatcher is on the stand.  He is fl by his son, Walter P. Thatcher Jr., and other partners. being questioned by some Merry Andrew congressmen.  At th moment, a baby alligator has just been placed in his lap, causing considerable confusion and embarrassment. Newsreel close-up of Thatcher, the soundtrack of which no fades in.
...  because of that trivial  incident...
It is a fact, however, is it not,  that in 1870, you did go to  Colorado?
I did.
In connection with the Kane affairs?
Yes.  My firm had been appointed  trustees by Mrs. Kane for the  fortune, which she had recently  acquired.  It was her wish that I  should take charge of this boy,  Charles Foster Kane.
That same month in Union Square -
Is it not a fact that on that  occasion, the boy personally  attacked you after striking you in  the stomach with a sled?
Loud laughter and confusion.
Mr. Chairman, I will read to this  committee a prepared statement I  have brought with me - and I will  then refuse to answer any further  questions.  Mr.  Johnson, please!
A young assistant hands him a sheet of paper from a brief

(reading it) "With full awareness of the meaning  of my words and the responsibility  of what I am about to say, it is  my considered belief that Mr.   Charles Foster Kane, in every  essence of his social beliefs and by the dangerous manner in which  he has persistently attacked the  American traditions of private  property, initiative and opportunity  for advancement, is - in fact -  nothing more or less than a  Communist."
Newsreel of Union Square meeting, section of crowd carryi banners urging the boycott of Kane papers.  A speaker is the platform above the crowd.
(fading in on  soundtrack) - till the words "Charles Foster  Kane" are a menace to every working  man in this land.  He is today  what he has always been and always  will be - A FASCIST!
And yet another opinion - Kane's  own.
Silent newsreel on a windy platform, flag-draped, in fron the magnificent Enquirer building.  On platform, in full  ceremonial dress, is Charles Foster Kane.  He orates sile

head_text.subj: "I AM, HAVE BEEN, AND WILL BE ONLY ONE THING

text: Same locale, Kane shaking hands out of frame. Another newsreel shot, much later, very brief, showing Ka older and much fatter, very tired-looking, seated with hi second wife in a nightclub.  He looks lonely and unhappy the midst of the gaiety.

Twice married, twice divorced -  first to a president's niece, Emily  Norton - today, by her second  marriage, chatelaine of the oldest  of England's stately homes.  Sixteen  years after that - two weeks after his divorce from Emily Norton -  Kane married Susan Alexander,  singer, at the Town Hall in Trenton,  New Jersey.

head_text.subj: FEW PRIVATE LIVES WERE MORE PUBLIC.

text: Period still of Emily Norton (1900).

Reconstructed silent newsreel.  Kane, Susan, and Bernstei emerging from side doorway of City Hall into a ring of pr photographers, reporters, etc.  Kane looks startled, reco for an instance, then charges down upon the photographers laying about him with his stick, smashing whatever he can

For wife two, one-time opera singing  Susan Alexander, Kane built  Chicago's Municipal Opera House.   Cost: three million dollars.   Conceived for Susan Alexander Kane,  half-finished before she divorced  him, the still unfinished Xanadu.   Cost: no man can say.
Still of architect's sketch with typically glorified "ren of the Chicago Municipal Opera House.

A glamorous shot of the almost-finished Xanadu, a magnifi fairy-tale estate built on a mountain. (1920) Then shots of its preparation. (1917) Shots of truck after truck, train after train, flashing b with tremendous noise. Shots of vast dredges, steamshovels. Shot of ship standing offshore unloading its lighters. In quick succession, shots follow each other, some  reconstructed, some in miniature, some real shots (maybe the dam projects) of building, digging, pouring concrete,

One hundred thousand trees, twenty  thousand tons of marble, are the  ingredients of Xanadu's mountain. Xanadu's livestock: the fowl of  the air, the fish of the sea, the  beast of the field and jungle -  two of each; the biggest private  zoo since Noah.  Contents of Kane's  palace: paintings, pictures,  statues, the very stones of many  another palace, shipped to Florida  from every corner of the earth,  from other Kane houses, warehouses,  where they mouldered for years.   Enough for ten museums - the loot  of the world.

More shots as before, only this time we see (in miniature large mountain - at different periods in its development rising out of the sands. Shots of elephants, apes, zebras, etc. being herded, unlo shipped, etc. in various ways. Shots of packing cases being unloaded from ships, from tr from trucks, with various kinds of lettering on them (Ita Arabian, Chinese, etc.) but all consigned to Charles Fost Kane, Xanadu, Florida. A reconstructed still of Xanadu - the main terrace.  A gr of persons in clothes of the period of 1917.  In their mi clearly recognizable, are Kane and Susan.

Kane urged his country's entry  into one war, opposed participation  in another.  Swung the election to  one American President at least,  was called another's assassin.   Thus, Kane's papers might never  have survived - had not the  President.

head_text.subj: FROM XANADU, FOR THE PAST TWENTY-FIVE YEARS, ALL KANE
ENTERPRISES HAVE BEEN DIRECTED, MANY OF THE NATIONS DESTI

text: Shots of various authentically worded headlines of Americ papers since 1895. Spanish-American War shots. (1898) A graveyard in France of the World War and hundreds of cr (1919)
Old newsreels of a political campaign. Insert of a particularly virulent headline and/or cartoon

Kane, molder of mass opinion though  he was, in all his life was never  granted elective office by the  voters of his country.  Few U.S.  news publishers have been. Few, like one-time Congressman  Hearst, have ever run for any office -  most know better - conclude with  other political observers that one  man's press has power enough for  himself.  But Kane papers were  once strong indeed, and once the  prize seemed almost his.  In 1910,  as Independent Candidate for  governor, the best elements of the  state behind him - the White House  seemingly the next easy step in a  lightning political career -

text: Newsreel shots of great crowds streaming into a building Madison Square Garden - then shots inside the vast audito at one end of which is a huge picture of Kane.  (1910) Shot of box containing the first Mrs. Kane and young Howa Kane, age five.  They are acknowledging the cheers of the (Silent Shot)  (1910) Newreel shot of dignitaries on platform, with Kane, along of speaker's table, beaming, hand upraised to silence the (Silent Shot)  (1910)

Then, suddenly - less than one  week before election - defeat!   Shameful, ignominious - defeat  that set back for twenty years the  cause of reform in the U.S., forever  cancelled political chances for  Charles Foster Kane.  Then, in the  third year of the Great  Depression...  As to all publishers,  it sometimes must - to Bennett, to  Munsey and Hearst it did - a paper  closes!  For Kane, in four short  years: collapse! Eleven Kane papers, four Kane  magazines merged, more sold,  scrapped -

Newreel shot - closeup of Kane delivering a speech...  (1 The front page of a contemporary paper - a screaming head Twin phots of Kane and Susan.  (1910) Printed title about Depression. Once more repeat the map of the USA 1932-1939.  Suddenly, cartoon goes into reverse, the empire begins to shrink,  illustrating the narrator's words. The door of a newspaper office with the signs: "Closed."

Then four long years more - alone  in his never-finished, already  decaying, pleasure palace, aloof,  seldom visited, never photographed,  Charles Foster Kane continued to  direct his falling empire ... vainly  attempting to sway, as he once  did, the destinies of a nation  that has ceased to listen to him  ... ceased to trust him...

Series of shots, entirely modern, but rather jumpy and ob bootlegged, showing Kane in a bath chair, swathed in summ rugs, being perambulated through his rose garden, a desol figure in the sunshine.  (1935)
Last week, death came to sit upon  the throne of America's Kubla Khan -  last week, as it must to all men,  death came to Charles Foster Kane.
Cabinent Photograph (Full Screen) of Kane as an old, old This image remains constant on the screen (as camera pull back, taking in the interior of a dark projection room.

A fairly large one, with a long throw to the screen.  It dark. The image of Kane as an old man remains constant on the s as camera pulls back, slowly taking in and registering  Projection Room.  This action occurs, however, only after first few lines of encuring dialogue have been spoken.  T shadows of the men speaking appear as they rise from thei chairs - black against the image of Kane's face on the sc NOTE:  These are the editors of a "News Digest" short, an the Rawlston magazines.  All his enterprises are represen in the projection room, and Rawlston himself, that great is present also and will shortly speak up. During the entire course of this scene, nobody's face is seen.  Sections of their bodies are picked out by a table a silhouette is thrown on the screen, and their faces and are themselves thrown into silhouette against the brillia slanting rays of light from the projection room. A Third Man is on the telephone.  We see a corner of his and the phone.
(at phone) Stand by.  I'll tell you if we  want to run it again. (hangs up)
Well?
A short pause.
It's a tough thing to do in a  newsreel.  Seventy years of a man's  life -

Murmur of highly salaried assent at this.  Rawlston walks camera and out of the picture.  Others are rising.  Camer during all of this, apparently does its best to follow ac and pick up faces, but fails.  Actually, all set-ups are planned very carefully to exclude the element of personal from this scene; which is expressed entirely by voices, s sillhouettes and the big, bright image of Kane himself on screen.
See what Arthur Ellis wrote about  him in the American review?
I read it.

(its owner is already  leaning across the  table, holding a  piece of paper  under the desk  light and reading  from it) Listen:  Kane is dead.  He  contributed to the journalism of  his day - the talent of a  mountebank, the morals of a  bootlegger, and the manners of a  pasha.  He and his kind have almost  succeeded in transforming a once  noble profession into a seven  percent security - no longer secure.
That's what Arthur Ellis is writing  now.  Thirty years ago, when Kane  gave him his chance to clean up  Detroit and Chicago and St. Louis,  Kane was the greatest guy in the world.  If you ask me -
Charles Foster Kane was a...
Then observations are made almost simultaneous.
Just a minute!
Camera moves to take in his bulk outlined against the glo from the projection room.
What were Kane's last words?
A silence greets this.
What were the last words he said  on earth?  Thompson, you've made  us a good short, but it needs  character -
Motivation -

That's it - motivation.  What made  Kane what he was?  And, for that  matter, what was he?  What we've  just seen are the outlines of a  career - what's behind the career?   What's the man?  Was he good or  bad?  Strong or foolish?  Tragic  or silly?  Why did he do all those  things?  What was he after? (then, appreciating  his point) Maybe he told us on his death bed.
Yes, and maybe he didn't.
Ask the question anyway, Thompson! Build the picture around the  question, even if you can't answer  it.
I know, but -
(riding over him  like any other  producer) All we saw on that screen was a  big American -
One of the biggest.
(without pausing  for this) But how is he different from Ford? Or Hearst for that matter?  Or  Rockefeller - or John Doe?
I know people worked for Kane will  tell you - not only in the newspaper  business - look how he raised  salaries.  You don't want to forget -
You take his labor record alone,  they ought to hang him up like a  dog.
I tell you, Thompson - a man's  dying words -
What were they?
Silence.
(hesitant) Yes, Mr. Rawlston, what were Kane's  dying words?
(with disgust) Rosebud!
A little ripple of laughter at this, which is promptly si by Rawlston.
That's right.
Tough guy, huh? (derisively) Dies calling for Rosebud!

Here's a man who might have been  President.  He's been loved and  hated and talked about as much as  any man in our time - but when he  comes to die, he's got something  on his mind called "Rosebud."   What does that mean?
A racehorse he bet on once,  probably, that didn't come in -  Rosebud!
All right.  But what was the race?
There is a short silence.
Thompson!
Yes, sir.
Hold this thing up for a week.   Two weeks if you have to...
(feebly) But don't you think if we release  it now - he's only been dead four  days it might be better than if -

(decisively) Nothing is ever better than finding  out what makes people tick.  Go  after the people that knew Kane  well.  That manager of his - the  little guy, Bernstein, those two  wives, all the people who knew  him, had worked for him, who loved  him, who hated his guts - (pauses) I don't mean go through the City Directory, of course -
The Third Man gives a hearty "yes-man" laugh.
I'll get to it right away, Mr. Rawlston.
(rising) Good!
The camera from behind him, outlines his back against Kan picture on the screen.
It'll probably turn out to be a  very simple thing...

NOTE:  Now begins the story proper - the seach by Thompso the facts about Kane - his researches ... his interviews the people who knew Kane. It is important to remember always that only at the very of the story is Thompson himself a personality.  Until th throughout the picture, we photograph only Thompson's bac shoulders, or his shadow - sometimes we only record his v He is not until the final scene a "character".  He is the personification of the search for the truth about Charles Kane.  He is the investigator.
The first image to register is a sign:

These words, spelled out in neon, glow out of the darknes the end of the fade out.  Then there is lightning which r a squalid roof-top on which the sign stands.  Thunder aga and faintly the sound of music from within.  A light glow from a skylight.  The camera moves to this and closes in. Through the splashes of rain, we see through the skylight into the interior of the cabaret.  Directly below us at a sits the lone figure of a woman, drinking by herself.

Medium shot of the same woman as before, finishing the dr she started to take above.  It is Susie.  The music, of c is now very loud.  Thompson, his back to the camera, move into the picture in the close foreground.  A Captain appe behind Susie, speaking across her to Thompson.
(a Greek) This is Mr. Thompson, Miss  Alexander.

Susan looks up into Thompson's face.  She is fifty, tryin look much younger, cheaply blonded, in a cheap, enormousl generous evening dress.  Blinking up into Thompson's face throws a crink into ther mouth.  Her eyes, which she thin keeping commandingly on his, are bleared and watery.
(to the Captain) I want another drink, John.
Low thunder from outside.
(seeing his chance) Right away.  Will you have  something, Mr. Thompson?
(staring to sit  down) I'll have a highball.
(so insistently as  to make Thompson  change his mind  and stand up again) Who told you you could sit down  here?
Oh!  I thought maybe we could have  a drink together?
Think again!
There is an awkward pause as Thompson looks from her to t Captain.
Why don't you people let me alone? I'm minding my own business.  You  mind yours.
If you'd just let me talk to you  for a little while, Miss Alexander. All I want to ask you...
Get out of here! (almost hysterical) Get out!  Get out!
Thompson looks at the Captain, who shrugs his shoulders.
I'm sorry.  Maybe some other time -
If he thought he would get a response from Susan, who thi she is looking at him steelily, he realizes his error.  H nods and walks off, following the Captain out the door.
She's just not talking to anybody  from the newspapers, Mr. Thompson.
I'm not from a newspaper exactly,  I -
They have come upon a waiter standing in front of a booth
(to the waiter) Get her another highball.
Another double?
(after a moment,  pityingly) Yes.
They walk to the door.
She's plastered, isn't she?
She'll snap out of it.  Why, until  he died, she'd just as soon talk  about Mr. Kane as about anybody.   Sooner.
I'll come down in a week or so and  see her again.  Say, you might be  able to help me.  When she used to  talk about Kane - did she ever  happen to say anything - about  Rosebud?
Rosebud?
Thompson has just handed him a bill.  The Captain pockets
Thank you, sir.  As a matter of  fact, yesterday afternoon, when it  was in all the papers - I asked  her.  She never heard of Rosebud.

An excruciatingly noble interpretation of Mr. Thatcher hi executed in expensive marble.  He is shown seated on one those improbable Edwin Booth chairs and is looking down, stone eyes fixed on the camera. We move down off of this, showing the impressive pedestal which the monument is founded.  The words, "Walter Parks  Thatcher" are prominently and elegantly engraved thereon. Immediately below the inscription we encounter, in a medi shot, the person of Bertha Anderson, an elderly, manish  spinnster, seated behind her desk.  Thompson, his hat in hand, is standing before her.  Bertha is on the phone.

(into phone) Yes.  I'll take him in now. (hangs up and looks  at Thompson) The directors of the Thatcher  Library have asked me to remind  you again of the condition under  which you may inspect certain  portions of Mr. Thatcher's  unpublished memoirs.  Under no  circumstances are direct quotations  from his manuscript to be used by  you.
That's all right.
You may come with me.
Without watching whether he is following her or not, she and starts towards a distant and imposingly framed door. Thompson, with a bit of a sigh, follows.

A room with all the warmth and charm of Napolean's tomb. As we dissolve in, the door opens in and we see past Thom shoulders the length of the room.  Everything very plain, much made out of marble and very gloomy.  Illumination fr skylight above adds to the general air of expensive and  classical despair.  The floor is marble, and there is a  gigantic, mahogany table in the center of everything.  Be this is to be seen, sunk in the marble wall at the far en the room, the safe from which a guard, in a khaki uniform with a revolver holster at his hip, is extracting the jou of Walter P. Thatcher.  He brings it to Bertha as if he w the guardian of a bullion shipment.  During this, Bertha been speaking.
(to the guard) Pages eighty-three to one hundred  and forty-two, Jennings.
Yes, Miss Anderson.
(to Thompson) You will confine yourself, it is  our understanding, to the chapter  dealing with Mr. Kane.
That's all I'm interested in.
The guard has, by this time, delivered the precious journ Bertha places it reverently on the table before Thompson.
You will be required to leave this  room at four-thirty promptly.

She leaves.  Thompson starts to light a cigarette.  The g shakes his head.  With a sigh, Thompson bends over to rea manuscript.  Camera moves down over his shoulder onto pag manuscript. Manuscript, neatly and precisely written:

I AM CONFIDENT THAT THE WHOLE WORLD WILL AGREE WITH MY OP
OF CHARLES FOSTER KANE, ASSUMING THAT HE IS NOT THEN COMP
FORGOTTEN, WHICH I REGARD AS EXTREMELY LIKELY. A GOOD DE
NONSENSE HAS APPEARED ABOUT MY FIRST MEETING WITH KANE, W
HE WAS SIX YEARS OLD... THE FACTS ARE SIMPLE. IN THE WI

text: The camera has not held on the entire page.  It has been  following the words with the same action that the eye doe reading.  On the last words, the white page of the paper

The white of a great field of snow, seen from the angle o parlor window. In the same position of the last word in above Insert, ap the tiny figure of Charles Foster Kane, aged five (almost an animated cartoon).  He is in the act of throwing a sno at the camera.  It sails toward us and over our heads, ou scene. Reverse angle - on the house featuring a large sign readi
Charles Kane's snowball hits the sign.

Camera is angling through the window, but the window-fram not cut into scene.  We see only the field of snow again, angle as in previous scene.  Charles is manufacturing ano snowball.  Now - Camera pulls back, the frame of the window appearing, and are inside the parlor of the boardinghouse.  Mrs. Kane, a about 28, is looking out towards her son.  Just as we tak in she speaks:
(calling out) Be careful, Charles!
Mrs. Kane -
(Calling out the  window almost on  top of this) Pull your muffler around your neck,  Charles -
But Charles, deliriously happy in the snow, is oblivious this and is running away.  Mrs. Kane turns into camera an see her face - a strong face, worn and kind.
think we'll have to tell him now -

Camera now pulls back further, showing Thatcher standing a table on which is his stove-pipe hat and an imposing  multiplicity of official-looking documents.  He is 26 and might be expected, a very stuffy young man, already very  expensive and conservative looking, even in Colorado.
I'll sign those papers -
You people seem to forget that I'm  the boy's father.

At the sound of Kane Sr.'s voice, both have turned to him the camera pulls back still further, taking him in. Kane Sr., who is the assistant curator in a livery stable been groomed as elegantly as is likely for this meeting e since daybreak. From outside the window can be heard faintly the wild and cheerful cries of the boy, blissfully cavorting in the sn
It's going to be done exactly the way I've told Mr. Thatcher -
If I want to, I can go to court. father has a right to -
(annoyed) Mr. Kane, the certificates that  Mr.  Graves left here are made out  to Mrs.  Kane, in her name.  Hers  to do with as she pleases -
Well, I don't hold with signing my  boy away to any bank as guardian just because -
(quietly) I want you to stop all this  nonsense, Jim.
The Bank's decision in all matters  concerning his education, his place  of residence and similar subjects  will be final. (clears his throat)
The idea of a bank being the  guardian -
Mrs. Kane has met his eye.  Her triumph over him finds  expression in his failure to finish his sentence.
(even more quietly) I want you to stop all this  nonsense, Jim.
We will assume full management of  the Colorado Lode - of which you,  Mrs. Kane, are the sole owner.
Kane Sr. opens his mouth once or twice, as if to say some but chokes down his opinion.
(has been reading  past Thatcher's  shoulder as he  talked) Where do I sign, Mr. Thatcher?
Right here, Mrs. Kane.
(sulkily) Don't say I didn't warn you.
Mrs. Kane lifts the quill pen.
Mary, I'm asking you for the last  time - anyon'd think I hadn't been a good husband and a -
Mrs. Kane looks at him slowly.  He stops his speech.
The sum of fifty thousand dollars  a year is to be paid to yourself  and Mr. Kane as long as you both  live, and thereafter the survivor -
Mrs. Kane puts pen to the paper and signs.
Well, let's hope it's all for the  best.
It is.  Go on, Mr. Thatcher -

Mrs. Kane, listening to Thatcher, of course has had her o ear bent in the direction of the boy's voice.  Thatcher i aware both of the boy's voice, which is counter to his ow and of Mrs. Kane's divided attention.  As he pauses, Kane genteelly walks over to close the window.
Kane Jr., seen from Kane Sr.'s position at the window.  H advancing on the snowman, snowballs in his hands, droppin one knee the better to confound his adversary.
If the rebels want a fight boys,  let's give it to 'em!
He throws two snowballs, missing widely, and gets up and  advances another five feet before getting on his knees ag
The terms are underconditional  surrender.  Up and at 'em!  The  Union forever!
Kane Sr. closes the window.

(over the boy's  voice) Everything else - the principal as  well as all monies earned - is to  be administered by the bank in  trust for your son, Charles Foster  Kane, until his twenty-fifth  birthday, at which time he is to  come into complete possession.
Mrs. Kane rises and goes to the window.
Go on, Mr. Thatcher.
Thatcher continues as she opens the window.  His voice, a before, is heard with overtones of the boy's.
Kane Jr., seen from Mrs. Kane's position at the window. now within ten feet of the snowman, with one snowball lef which he is holding back in his right hand.
You can't lick Andy Jackson!  Old  Hickory, that's me!
He fires his snowball, well wide of the mark and falls fl his stomach, starting to crawl carefully toward the snowm
It's nearly five, Mrs. Kane, don't you think I'd better meet the boy -
Mrs. Kane at the window.  Thatcher is now standing at her
I've got his trunk all packed - (she chokes a little) I've it packed for a couple of  weeks -
She can't say anymore.  She starts for the hall day.  Kan Sr., ill at ease, has no idea of how to comfort her.
I've arranged for a tutor to meet  us in Chicago.  I'd have brought  him along with me, but you were so anxious to keep everything secret -

He stops as he realizes that Mrs. Kane has paid no attent to him and, having opened the door, is already well into hall that leads to the side door of the house.  He takes look at Kane Sr., tightens his lips and follows Mrs. Kane Kane, shoulders thrown back like one who bears defeat bra follows him.

Kane, in the snow-covered field.  With the snowman betwee and the house, he is holding the sled in his hand, just a to make the little run that prefaces a belly-flop.  The K house, in the background, is a dilapidated, shabby, two-s frame building, with a wooden outhouse.  Kane looks up as sees the single file procession, Mrs. Kane at its head, c toward him.
H'ya, Mom.
Mrs. Kane smiles.
(gesturing at the  snowman) See, Mom?  I took the pipe out of  his mouth.  If it keeps on snowin', maybe I'll make some teeth and -
You better come inside, son.  You  and I have got to get you all ready for - for -
Charles, my name is Mr. Thatcher -
This is Mr. Thatcher, Charles.
How do you do, Charles?
He comes from the east.
Hello.  Hello, Pop.
Hello, Charlie!
Mr. Thatcher is going to take you  on a trip with him tonight, Charles. You'll be leaving on Number Ten.
That's the train with all the  lights.
You goin', Mom?
Your mother won't be going right  away, Charles -
Where'm I going?
You're going to see Chicago and  New York - and Washington, maybe... Isn't he, Mr. Thatcher?
(heartily) He certainly is.  I wish I were a  little boy and going to make a  trip like that for the first time.
Why aren't you comin' with us,  Mom?
We have to stay here, Charles.

You're going to live with Mr.  Thatcher from now on, Charlie!   You're going to be rich.  Your Ma  figures - that is, re - she and I  have decided that this isn't the  place for you to grow up in. You'll probably be the richest man  in America someday and you ought  to -
You won't be lonely, Charles...
We're going to have a lot of good  times together, Charles...  Really  we are.
Kane stares at him.
Come on, Charles.  Let's shake  hands. (extends his hand.   Charles continues  to look at him) Now, now!  I'm not as frightening  as all that!  Let's shake, what do  you say?
He reaches out for Charles's hand.  Without a word, Charl hits him in the stomach with the sled.  Thatcher stumbles a few feet, gasping.

(with a sickly grin) You almost hurt me, Charles. (moves towards him) Sleds aren't to hit people with. Sleds are to - to sleigh on.  When  we get to New York, Charles, we'll get you a sled that will -
He's near enough to try to put a hand on Kane's shoulder. he does, Kane kicks him in the ankle.
Charles!
He throws himself on her, his arms around her.  Slowly Mr Kane puts her arms around him.
(frightened) Mom!  Mom!
It's all right, Charles, it's all  right.
Thatcher is looking on indignantly, occasionally bending to rub his ankle.
Sorry, Mr. Thatcher!  What the kid  needs is a good thrashing!
That's what you think, is it, Jim?
Yes.
Mrs. Kane looks slowly at Mr. Kane.
(slowly) That's why he's going to be brought  up where you can't get at him.
Old-fashioned railroad wheels underneath a sleeper, spinn along the track.

Thatcher, with a look of mingled exasperation, annoyance, sympathy and inability to handle the situation, is standi alongside a berth, looking at Kane.  Kane, his face in th pillow, is crying with heartbreaking sobs.
Mom!  Mom!
The white page of the Thatcher manuscript.  We pick up th words:

head_text.subj: "HE WAS, I REPEAT, A COMMON ADVENTURER, SPOILED, UNSCRUPU

text: The words are followed by printed headline on "Enquirer" (as in following scene).
Close-up on printed headline which reads:

Camera pulls back to reveal Thatcher holding the "Enquire copy, on which we read the headline.  He is standing near editorial round table around which a section of the staff including Reilly, Leland and Kane are eating lunch.
(coldly) Is that really your idea of how to  run a newspaper?
I don't know how to run a newspaper,  Mr. Thatcher.  I just try everything  I can think of.
(reading headline  of paper he is  still holding) "Enemy Armada Off Jersey Coast."   You know you haven't the slightest  proof that this - this armada - is  off the Jersey Coast.
Can you prove it isn't?
Bernstein has come into the picture.  He has a cable in h hand.  He stops when he sees Thatcher.
Mr. Bernstein, Mr. Thatcher -
How are you, Mr. Thatcher?
How do you do? -
We just had a wire from Cuba, Mr.  Kane - (stops, embarrassed)

That's all right.  We have no  secrets from our readers.  Mr.  Thatcher is one of our most devoted  readers, Mr.  Bernstein.  He knows  what's wrong with every issue since  I've taken charge.  What's the  cable?

(reading) The food is marvelous in Cuba the  senoritas are beautiful stop I  could send you prose poems of palm  trees and sunrises and tropical  colors blending in far off  landscapes but don't feel right in  spending your money for this stop  there's no war in Cuba regards  Wheeler.
You see!  There hasn't been a true  word -

I think we'll have to send our  friend Wheeler a cable, Mr.  Bernstein.  Of course, we'll have  to make it shorter than his, because  he's working on an expense account  and we're not.  Let me see - (snaps his fingers) Mike!
(a fairly tough  customer prepares  to take dictation,  his mouth still  full of food) Go ahead, Mr. Kane.
Dear Wheeler - (pauses a moment) You provide the prose poems - I'll  provide the war.
Laughter from the boys and girls at the table.
That's fine, Mr. Kane.
I rather like it myself.  Send it  right away.
Right away.
Right away.
Mike and Bernstein leave.  Kane looks up, grinning at Tha who is bursting with indignation but controls himself.  A a moment of indecision, he decides to make one last try.
I came to see you, Charles, about  your - about the Enquirer's campaign  against the Metropolitan Transfer  Company.
Won't you step into my office, Mr. Thatcher?
They cross the City Room together.
I think I should remind you,  Charles, of a fact you seem to  have forgotten.  You are yourself  one of the largest individual  stockholders.
Kane holds the door open for Thatcher.  They come in toge
Mr. Thatcher, isn't everything  I've been saying in the Enquirer  about the traction trust absolutely  true?
(angrily) They're all part of your general attack - your senseless attack - on everything and everybody who's  got more than ten cents in his  pocket.  They're -
The trouble is, Mr. Thatcher, you  don't realize you're talking to two people.
Kane moves around behind his desk.  Thatcher doesn't unde looks at him.

As Charles Foster Kane, who has                          eighty-two thousand, six hundred  and thirty-one shares of  Metropolitan Transfer - you see, I  do have a rough idea of my holdings - I sympathize with you.  Charles  Foster Kane is a dangerous  scoundrel, his paper should be run  out of town and a committee should  be formed to boycott him.  You  may, if you can form such a  committee, put me down for a  contribution of one thousand  dollars.
(angrily) Charles, my time is too valuable  for me -

On the other hand - (his manner becomes  serious) I am the publisher of the Enquirer. As such, it is my duty - I'll let  you in on a little secret, it is  also my pleasure - to see to it  that decent, hard-working people  of this city are not robbed blind  by a group of money - mad pirates  because, God help them, they have  no one to look after their  interests!  I'll let you in on  another little secret, Mr. Thatcher.   I think I'm the man to do it.  You  see, I have money and property -
Thatcher doesn't understand him.
If I don't defend the interests of  the underprivileged, somebody else  will - maybe somebody without any  money or any property and that  would be too bad.
Thatcher glares at him, unable to answer.  Kane starts to
Do you know how to tap, Mr.  Thatcher?  You ought to learn - (humming quietly,  he continues to  dance)
Thatcher puts on his hat.

I happened to see your consolidated  statement yesterday, Charles.   Could I not suggest to you that it  is unwise for you to continue this  philanthropic enterprise - (sneeringly) this Enquirer - that is costing  you one million dollars a year?
You're right.  We did lose a million  dollars last year.
Thatcher thinks maybe the point has registered.
We expect to lost a million next year, too.  You know, Mr. Thatcher - (starts tapping  quietly) at the rate of a million a year - we'll have to close this place in  sixty years.

Thompson - at the desk.  With a gesture of annoyance, he closing the manuscript. Camera arcs quickly around from over his shoulder to hold door behind him, missing his face as he rises and turns t confront Miss Anderson, who has come into the room to sho out.  Very prominent on this wall is an over-sized oil pa of Thatcher in the best Union League Club renaissance sty
You have enjoyed a very rare  privilege, young man.  Did you  find what you were looking for?
No.  Tell me something, Miss  Anderson.  You're not Rosebud, are  you?
What?
I didn't think you were.  Well,  thanks for the use of the hall.
He puts his hat on his head and starts out, lighting a ci as he goes.  Miss Anderson, scandalized, watches him.

Closeup of a still of Kane, aged about sixty-five.  Camer pulls back, showing it is a framed photograph on the wall Over the picture are crossed American flags.  Under it si Bernstein, back of his desk.  Bernstein, always an unders Jew, now seems even smaller than in his youth.  He is bal an egg, spry, with remarkably intense eyes.  As camera co to travel back, the back of Thompson's head and his shoul come into the picture.
(wryly) Who's a busy man?  Me?  I'm Chairman  of the Board.  I got nothing but  time ...  What do you want to know?
(still explaining) Well, Mr. Bernstein, you were with  Mr.  Kane from the very beginning -
From before the beginning, young  fellow.  And now it's after the  end. (turns to Thompson) Anything you want to know about  him - about the paper -
-  We thought maybe, if we can  find out what he meant by that  last word - as he was dying -
That Rosebud?  Maybe some girl?   There were a lot of them back in  the early days, and -
Not some girl he knew casually and  then remembered after fifty years, on his death bed -

You're pretty young, Mr. - (remembers the name) Mr. Thompson.  A fellow will  remember things you wouldn't think  he'd remember.  You take me.  One  day, back in 1896, I was crossing  over to Jersey on a ferry and as  we pulled out, there was another ferry pulling in - (slowly) - and on it, there was a girl  waiting to get off.  A white dress  she had on - and she was carrying  a white pastrol - and I only saw  her for one second and she didn't  see me at all - but I'll bet a  month hasn't gone by since that I  haven't thought of that girl. (triumphantly) See what I mean? (smiles) Well, so what are you doing about  this "Rosebud," Mr. Thompson.
I'm calling on people who knew Mr.  Kane.  I'm calling on you.
Who else you been to see?
Well, I went down to Atlantic City -
Susie?  I called her myself the  day after he died.  I thought maybe  somebody ought to... (sadly) She couldn't even come to the  'phone.
You know why?  She was so -
Sure, sure.
I'm going back there.
Who else did you see?
Nobody else, but I've been through  that stuff of Walter Thatcher's. That journal of his -
Thatcher!  That man was the biggest darn fool I ever met -
He made an awful lot of money.
It's not trick to make an awful  lot of money if all you want is to  make a lot of money. (his eyes get  reflective) Thatcher!
Bernstein looks out of the window and keeps on looking, s to see something as he talks.

He never knew there was anything  in the world but money.  That kind  of fellow you can fool every day  in the week - and twice on Sundays! (reflectively) The time he came to Rome for Mr.  Kane's twenty-fifth birthday...   You know, when Mr. Kane got control  of his own money...  Such a fool like Thatcher - I tell you, nobody's business!
Bernstein speaking to Thompson.

He knew what he wanted, Mr. Kane  did, and he got it!  Thatcher never  did figure him out.  He was hard  to figure sometimes, even for me.   Mr. Kane was a genius like he said.   He had that funny sense of humor.   Sometimes even I didn't get the  joke.  Like that night the opera  house of his opened in Chicago...   You know, the opera house he built  for Susie, she should be an opera  singer... (indicates with a  little wave of his  hand what he thinks  of that; sighing) That was years later, of course -  1914 it was.  Mrs. Kane took the  leading part in the opera, and she  was terrible.  But nobody had the  nerve to say so - not even the  critics.  Mr. Kane was a big man  in those days.  But this one fellow,  this friend of his, Branford Leland -
He leaves the sentence up in the air, as we

It is late.  The room is almost empty.  Nobody is at work the desks.  Bernstein, fifty, is waiting anxiously with a group of Kane's hirelings, most of them in evening dress overcoats and hats.  Eveybody is tense and expectant.
(turns to a young  hireling; quietly) What about Branford Leland?  Has  he got in his copy?
Not yet.
Go in and ask him to hurry.
Well, why don't you, Mr. Bernstein? You know Mr. Leland.
(looks at him for a  moment; then slowly) I might make him nervous.
(after a pause) You and Leland and Mr. Kane - you  were great friends back in the old  days, I understand.
(with a smile) That's right.  They called us the  "Three Musketeers."
Somebody behind Bernstein has trouble concealing his laug The City Editor speaks quickly to cover the situation.
He's a great guy - Leland. (another little  pause) Why'd he ever leave New York?
(he isn't saying) That's a long story.
(a tactless one) Wasn't there some sort of quarrel  between -

(quickly) I had nothing to do with it. (then, somberly) It was Leland and Mr. Kane, and  you couldn't call it a quarrel  exactly.  Better we should forget  such things - (turning to City  Editor) Leland is writing it up from the  dramatic angle?
Yes.  I thought it was a good idea. We've covered it from the news  end, of course.
And the social.  How about the  music notice?  You got that in?
Oh, yes, it's already made up.   Our Mr. Mervin wrote a small review.
Enthusiastic?
Yes, very! (quietly) Naturally.
Well, well - isn't that nice?
Mr. Bernstein -
Bernstein turns. Medium long shot of Kane, now forty-nine, already quite s He is in white tie, wearing his overcoat and carrying a f opera hat.
Hello, Mr. Kane.
The Hirelings rush, with Bernstein, to Kane's side.  Wide half-suppressed sensation.
Mr. Kane, this is a surprise!
We've got a nice plant here.
Everybody falls silent.  There isn't anything to say.
Was the show covered by every  department?
Exactly according to your  instructions, Mr. Kane.  We've got  two spreads of pictures.
(very, very casually) And the notice?
Yes - Mr. Kane.
(quietly) Is it good?
Yes, Mr. kane.
Kane looks at him for a minute.
But there's another one still to  come - the dramatic notice.
(sharply) It isn't finished?
No, Mr. Kane.
That's Leland, isn't it?
Yes, Mr. Kane.
Has he said when he'll finish?
We haven't heard from him.
He used to work fast - didn't he,  Mr. Bernstein?
He sure did, Mr. Kane.
Where is he?
Right in there, Mr. Kane.
The Hireling indicates the closed glass door of a little at the other end of the City Room.  Kane takes it in.
(helpless, but very  concerned) MR. KANE -
That's all right, Mr. Bernstein.

Kane crosses the length of the long City Room to the glas door indicated before by the Hireling.  The City Editor l at Bernstein.  Kane opens the door and goes into the offi closing the door behind him.
Leland and Mr. Kane - they haven't  spoke together for ten years. (long pause; finally) Excuse me. (starts toward the  door)

Bernstein comes in.  An empty bottle is standing on Lelan desk.  He has fallen over his typewriter, his face on the A sheet of paper is in the machine.  A paragraph has been Kane is standing at the other side of the desk looking do him.  This is the first time we see murder in Kane's face Bernstein looks at Kane, then crosses to Leland.  He shak him.
Hey, Brad!  Brad! (he straightens,  looks at Kane;  pause) He ain't been drinking before, Mr.  Kane.  Never.  We would have heard.
(finally; after a  pause) What does it say there?
Bernstein stares at him.
What's he written?
Bernstein looks over nearsightedly, painfully reading the paragraph written on the page.

(reading) "Miss Susan Alexander, a pretty  but hopelessly incompetent amateur - (he waits for a  minute to catch  his breath; he  doesn't like it) - last night opened the new Chicago  Opera House in a performance of -  of -" (looks up miserably) I can't pronounce that name, Mr.  Kane.
Thais.
Bernstein looks at Kane for a moment, then looks back, to
(reading again) "Her singing, happily, is no concern  of this department.  Of her acting,  it is absolutely impossible to..." (he continues to  stare at the page)
(after a short  silence) Go on!
(without looking up) That's all there is.
Kane snatches the paper from the roller and reads it for  himself.  Slowly, a queer look comes over his face.  Then speaks, very quietly.
Of her acting, it is absolutely  impossible to say anything except  that it represents a new low... (then sharply) Have you got that, Mr. Bernstein? In the opinion of this reviewer -
(miserably) I didn't see that.
It isn't here, Mr. Bernstein.  I'm  dictating it.
(looks at him) I can't take shorthand.
Get me a typewriter.  I'll finish  the notice.
Bernstein retreats from the room.
Long shot of Kane in his shirt sleeves, illuminated by a light, typing furiously.  As the camera starts to pull ev farther away from this, and as Bernstein - as narrator - to speak -
Bernstein speaking to Thompson.
He finished it.  He wrote the worst  notice I ever read about the girl  he loved.  We ran it in every paper.
(after a pause) I guess Mr. Kane didn't think so  well of Susie's art anyway.

(looks at him very  soberly) He thought she was great, Mr.  Thompson.  He really believed that.   He put all his ambition on that  girl.  After she came along, he  never really cared for himself  like he used to.  Oh, I don't blame Susie -
Well, then, how could he write  that roast?  The notices in the  Kane papers were always very kind  to her.

Oh, yes.  He saw to that.  I tell  you, Mr. Thompson, he was a hard  man to figure out.  He had that  funny sense of humor.  And then,  too, maybe he thought by finishing  that piece he could show Leland he  was an honest man.  You see, Leland  didn't think so.  I guess he showed  him all right.  He's a nice fellow,  but he's a dreamer.  They were  always together in those early  days when we just started the  Enquirer.
On these last words, we

The front half of the second floor constitutes one large Room.  Despite the brilliant sunshine outside, very littl it is actually getting into the room because the windows small and narrow.  There are about a dozen tables and des of the old-fashioned type, not flat, available for report Two tables, on a raised platform at the end of the room,  obviously serve the city room executives.  To the left of platform is an open door which leads into the Sanctrum. As Kane and Leland enter the room, an elderly, stout gent the raised platform, strikes a bell and the other eight  occupants of the room - all men - rise and face the new  arrivals.  Carter, the elderly gent, in formal clothes, r and starts toward them.
Welcome, Mr. Kane, to the  "Enquirer."  I am Herbert Carter.
Thank you, Mr Carter.  This is Mr. Leland.
(bowing) How do you do, Mr. Leland?
(pointing to the  standing reporters) Are they standing for me?
I thought it would be a nice gesture the new publisher -
(grinning) Ask them to sit down.
You may resume your work, gentlemen. (to Kane) I didn't know your plans and so I  was unable to make any preparations.
I don't my plans myself.
They are following Carter to his raised platform.
As a matter of fact, I haven't got  any.  Except to get out a newspaper.
There is a terrific crash at the doorway.  They all turn see Bernstein sprawled at the entrance.  A roll of beddin suitcase, and two framed pictures were too much for him.
Oh, Mr. Bernstein!
Bernstein looks up.
If you would come here a moment, please, Mr. Bernstein?
Bernstein rises and comes over, tidying himself as he com
Mr. Carter, this is Mr. Bernstein. Mr. Bernstein is my general manager.
(frigidly) How do you do, Mr. Bernstein?
You've got a private office here,  haven't you?
The delivery wagon driver has now appeared in the entranc with parts of the bedstead and other furniture.  He is lo about, a bit bewildered.
(indicating open  door to left of  platform) My little sanctum is at your  disposal.  But I don't think I  understand -
I'm going to live right here. (reflectively) As long as I have to.
But a morning newspaper, Mr. Kane. After all, we're practically closed  twelve hours a day - except for  the business offices -
That's one of the things I think  must be changed, Mr. Carter.  The  news goes on for twenty-four hours  a day.

Kane, in his shirt sleeves, at a roll-top desk in the San is working feverishly on copy and eating a very sizeable at the same time.  Carter, still formally coated, is seat alongside him.  Leland, seated in a corner, is looking on detached, amused.  The furniture has been pushed around a Kane's effects are somewhat in place.  On a corner of the Bernstein is writing down figures.  No one pays any atten to him.

I'm not criticizing, Mr. Carter,  but here's what I mean.  There's a  front page story in the "Chronicle," (points to it) and a picture - of a woman in  Brooklyn who is missing.  Probably  murdered. (looks to make sure  of the name) A Mrs. Harry Silverstone.  Why  didn't the "Enquirer" have that  this morning?
(stiffly) Because we're running a newspaper,  Mr.  Kane, not a scandal sheet.
Kane has finished eating.  He pushes away his plates.
I'm still hungry, Brad.  Let's go  to Rector's and get something  decent. (pointing to the  "Chronicle" before  him) The "Chronicle" has a two-column  headline, Mr. Carter.  Why haven't  we?
There is no news big enough.
If the headline is big enough, it  makes the new big enough.  The  murder of Mrs. Harry Silverstone -

(hotly) As a matter of fact, we sent a man  to the Silverstone home yesterday  afternoon. (triumphantly) Our man even arrived before the  "Chronicle" reporter.  And there's  no proof that the woman was murdered - or even that she's dead.
(smiling a bit) The "Chronicle" doesn't say she's  murdered, Mr. Carter.  It says the  neighbors are getting suspicious.
(stiffly) It's not our function to report  the gossip of housewives.  If we  were interested in that kind of  thing, Mr. Kane, we could fill the  paper twice over daily -

(gently) That's the kind of thing we are  going to be interested in from now  on, Mr. Carter.  Right now, I wish  you'd send your best man up to see  Mr. Silverstone.  Have him tell  Mr.  Silverstone if he doesn't  produce his wife at once, the  "Enquirer" will have him arrested. (he gets an idea) Have him tell Mr. Silverstone he's  a detective from the Central Office. If Mr. Silverstone asks to see his  badge, your man is to get indignant  and call Mr. Silverstone an  anarchist.
Loudly, so that the neighbors can hear.
Really, Mr. Kane, I can't see the function of a respectable newspaper -
Kane isn't listening to him.
Oh, Mr. Bernstein!
Bernstein looks up from his figures.
I've just made a shocking discovery. The "Enquirer" is without a  telephone.  Have two installed at  once!
I ordered six already this morning! Got a discount!
Kane looks at Leland with a fond nod of his head at Berns Leland grins back.  Mr. Carter, meantime, has risen stiff
But, Mr. Kane -
That'll be all today, Mr. Carter. You've been most understanding. Good day, Mr. Carter!
Carter, with a look that runs just short of apoplexy, lea the room, closing the door behind him.
Poor Mr. Carter!
(shakes his head) What makes those fellows think  that a newspaper is something rigid,  something inflexible, that people are supposed to pay two cents for -
(without looking up) Three cents.
(calmly) Two cents.
Bernstein lifts his head and looks at Kane.  Kane gazes b at him.
(tapping on the  paper) This is all figured at three cents  a copy.
Re-figure it, Mr. Bernstein, at  two cents.
(sighs and puts  papers in his pocket) All right, but I'll keep these  figures, too, just in case.
Ready for dinner, Brad?

Mr. Leland, if Mr. Kane, he should  decide to drop the price to one  cent, or maybe even he should make  up his mind to give the paper away  with a half-pound of tea - you'll  just hold him until I get back,  won't you?
I'm not guaranteeing a thing, Mr. Bernstein.  You people work too  fast for me!  Talk about new brooms!
Who said anything about brooms?
It's a saying, Mr. Bernstein.  A  new broom sweeps clean.
Oh!

The ground floor witht he windows on the street - of the  "Enquirer."  It is almost midnight by an old-fashioned cl on the wall.  Grouped around a large table, on which are locked forms of type, very old-fashioned of course, but t to the period - are Kane and Leland in elegant evening cl Bernstein, unchanged from the afternoon, and Smathers, th composing room foreman, nervous and harassed.
But it's impossible, Mr. Kane.  We  can't remake these pages.
These pages aren't made up as I  want them, Mr. Smathers.  We go to  press in five minutes.
(about to crack up) The "Enquirer" has an old and  honored tradition, Mr. Kane...   The "Enquirer" is not in competition  with those other rags.
We should be publishing such rags, that's all I wish.  Why, the  "Enquirer" - I wouldn't wrap up  the liver for the cat in the  "Enquirer" -
(enraged) Mr. Kane, I must ask you to see to  it that this - this person learns  to control his tongue.
Kane looks up.

I've been a newspaperman my whole  life and I don't intend - (he starts to sputter) - if it's your intention that I  should continue to be harassed by  this - this - (he's really sore) I warn you, Mr. Kane, it would go  against my grain to desert you  when you need me so badly - but I  would feel obliged to ask that my  resignation be accepted.
It is accepted, Mr. Carter, with  assurances of my deepest regard.
But Mr. Kane, I meant -
Kane turns his back on him, speaks again to the composing foreman.
(quietly) Let's remake these pages, Mr.  Smathers.  We'll have to publish a  half hour late, that's all.
(as though Kane  were talking Greek) We can't remake them, Mr. Kane.   We go to press in five minutes.
Kane sighs, unperturbed, as he reaches out his hand and s the forms off the table onto the floor, where they scatte into hundreds of bits.
You can remake them now, can't  you, Mr. Smathers?
Smather's mouth opens wider and wider.  Bradford and Bern are grinning.

After the types 've been reset and  the pages have been remade according  to the way I told you before, Mr. Smathers, kindly have proofs pulled  and bring them to me.  Then, if I  can't find any way to improve them again - (almost as if  reluctantly) - I suppose we'll have to go to  press.
He starts out of the room, followed by Leland.
(to Smathers) In case you don't understand, Mr. Smathers - he's a new broom.

The picture is mainly occupied by a large building, on th roof of which the lights spell out the word "Enquirer" ag the sunrise.  We do not see the street or the first few s of this building, the windows of which would be certainly illuminated.  What we do see is the floor on which is loc the City Room.  Over this scene, newboys are heard sellin Chronicle, their voices growing in volume. As the dissolve complete itself, camera moves toward the lighted window - the window of the Sanctrum.

The newsboys are still heard from the street below - fain but very insistent. Kane's office is gas-lit, of course, as is the rest of th Enquirer building. Kane, in his shirt sleeves, stands at the open window loo out.  The bed is already made up.  On it is seated Bernst smoking the end of a cigar.  Leland is in a chair.
CHRONICLE!  CHRONICLE!  H'YA - THE  CHRONICLE - GET YA!  CHRONICLE!
Kane, taking a deep breath of the morning air, closes the and turns to the others.  The voices of the newsboys, nat are very much fainter after this.
We'll be on the street soon, Charlie -  another ten minutes.
(looking at his  watch) It's three hours and fifty minutes late - but we did it -
Leland rises from the chair, stretching painfully.
Tired?
It's been a tough day.
A wasted day.
(looking up) Wasted?
(incredulously) Charlie?!
You just made the paper over four times today, Mr. Kane.  That's all -

I've changed the front page a  little, Mr. Bernstein.  That's not  enough - There's something I've  got to get into this paper besides  pictures and print -  I've got to  make the "New York Enquirer" as  important to New York as the gas  in that light.
(quietly) What're you going to do, Charlie?
Kane looks at him for a minute with a queer smile of happ concentration.
My Declaration of Principles - (he says it with  quotes around it) Don't smile, Brad - (getting the idea) Take dictation, Mr. Bernstein -
Can't take shorthand, Mr. Kane -
I'll write it myself.
Kane grabs a piece of rough paper and a grease crayon.  S down on the bed next to Bernstein, he starts to write.
(looking over his  shoulder) You don't wanta make any promises,  Mr. Kane, you don't wanta keep.

(as he writes) These'll be kept. (stops for a minute  and reads what he  has written; reading) I'll provide the people of this  city with a daily paper that will  tell all the news honestly. (starts to write  again; reading as  he writes) will also provide them -
That's the second sentence you've started with "I" -

(looking up) People are going to know who's  responsible.  And they're going to get the news - the true news - quickly and simply and  entertainingly. (he speaks with  real conviction) And no special interests will be  allowed to interfere with the truth  of that news.

He looks at Leland for a minute and goes back to his writ reading as he writes. Bernstein has risen and crossed to one side of Kane.  The both stand looking out.  Leland joins him on the other si Their three heads are silhouetted against the sky.  Lelan head is seen to turn slightly as he looks into Kane's fac camera very close on this - Kane turns to him and we know eyes have met, although their faces are almost in sillhou Bernstein is still smoking a cigar.
Front page of the "Enquirer" shows big boxed editorial wi heading:

Camera continues pulling back and shows newspaper to be o top of a pile of newspapers.  As we draw further back, we four piles, and as camera contines to pull back, we see s piles and go on back until we see a big field of "Enquire piles of "Enquirers" - all 26,000 copies ready for distri A wagon with a huge sign on its side reading

passes through foreground, and we wipe to: A pile of "Enquirers" for sale on a broken down wooden bo a street corner, obviously a poor district.  A couple of fall on the pile. The stoop of a period door with old-fashioned enamel milk and a bag of rolls.  Across the sidewalk before this, mov the shadow of an old-fashioned bicycle with an enormous f wheel.  A copy of the "Enquirer" is tossed on the stoop. A breakfast table - beautiful linen and beautiful silver everything very expensive, gleaming in the sunshine.  Int silver newspaper rack there is slipped a copy of the "Enq Here, as before, the boxed editorial reading MY PRINCIPLE DECLARATION BY CHARLES FOSTER KANE, is very prominent on front page. The wooden floor of a railroad station, flashing light an dark as a train behind the camera rushes by.  On the floo there is tossed a bound bundle of the "New York Enquirer" the Declaration of Principles still prominent. Rural Delivery - a copy of the "Enquirer"s being put into showing state distribution. The railroad platform again.  We stay here for four image On each image, the speed of the train is faster and the p of the "Enquirer" are larger.  On the first image, we mov to hold on the words "CIRCULATION - 31,000."  We are this for the next pile which reads 40,000; the next one which 55,000, and the last which is 62,000.  In each instance, bundles of newspapers are thicker and the speed of the mo train behind the camera is increased. The entire montage above indicated is accompanied by a  descriptive complement of sound - the traffic noises of N York in the 1890's; wheels on cobblestones and horses' ho bicycle bells; the mooning of cattle and the crowing of r (in the RFD shot), and in all cases where the railroad pl is used - the mounting sound of the railroad train. The last figure "62,000" opposite the word "CIRCULATION" the "Enquirer" masthead changes to:
Angle up to wall of building - a painter on a cradle is p the last zero to the figure "62,000" on an enormous sign  advertising the "Enquirer."  It reads:

head_text.subj: THE ENQUIRER THE PEOPLE'S NEWSPAPER CIRCULATION 62,000

text: Camera travels down side of building - takes in another b on which there is a sign which reads:

head_text.subj: READ THE ENQUIRER AMERICA'S FINEST CIRCULATION 62,000

text: Camera continues to travel down to sidewalk in front of t Chronicle office.  The Chronicle office has a plateglass in which is reflected traffic moving up and down the stre also the figures of Kane, Leland and Bernstein, who are m peanuts. Inside the window, almost filling it, is a large photogra the "Chronicle" staff, with Reilly prominently seated in center.  A sign over the photo reads: EDITORIAL AND EXECU STAFF OF THE NEW YORK CHRONICLE.  A sign beneath it reads GREATEST NEWSPAPER STAFF IN THE WORLD.  The sign also inc the "Chronicle" circulation figure.  There are nine men i photo.
(looking up at the  sign - happily) Sixty-two thousand -
That looks pretty nice.
(indicating the  Chronicle Building) Let's hope they like it there.
From the Chronicle Building that  sign is the biggest thing you can  see - every floor guaranteed -  let's hope it bothers them - it  cost us enough.
(pointing to the  sign over the  photograph in the  window) Look at that.
The "Chronicle" is a good newspaper.
It's a good idea for a newspaper. (reading the figures) Four hundred sixy thousand.
Say, with them fellows - (referring to the  photo) - it's no trick to get circulation.
You're right, Mr. Bernstein.
(sighs) You know how long it took the  "Chronicle" to get that staff  together?  Twenty years.
I know.
Kane, smiling, lights a cigarette, at the same time looki into the window.  Camera moves in to hold on the photogra nine men, still holding the reflection of Kane's smiling

Nine men, arrayed as in the photograph, but with Kane bea in the center of the first row.  The men, variously with  mustaches, beards, bald heads, etc. are easily identified being the same men, Reilly prominent amongst them. As camera pulls back, it is revealed that they are being  photographed - by an old-type professional photographer, box, black hood and all - in a corner of the room.  It is at night.  Desks, etc. have been pushed against the wall. Running down the center of the room is a long banquet tab at which twenty diners have finished their meals.  The el remaining at their seats - these include Bernstein and Le are amusedly watching the photographic ceremonies.
That's all.  Thank you.
The photographic subjects rise.
(a sudden thought) Make up an extra copy and mail it  to the "Chronicle."
Chuckling and beaming, he makes his way to his place at t head of the table.  The others have already sat down.  Ka gets his guests' attention by rapping on the table with a

Gentlemen of the "Enquirer"!  This  has, I think, been a fitting welcome to those distinguished journalists - (indicates the eight  men) Mr. Reilly in particular - who are  the latest additions to our ranks. It will make them happy to learn  that the "Enquirer's" circulation  this morning passed the two hundred  thousand mark.
Two hundred and one thousand, six  hundred and forty-seven.
General applause.

All of you - new and old -  You're  all getting the best salaries in  town.  Not one of you has been  hired because of his loyalty.   It's your talent I'm interested  in.  That talent that's going to  make the "Enquirer" the kind of  paper I want - the best newspaper  in the world!
Applause.
However, I think you'll agree we've  heard enough about newspapers and  the newspaper business for one  night.  There are other subjects  in the world.

He puts his two fingers in his mouth and lets out a shril whistle.  This is a signal.  A band strikes up a lively d of the period and enters in advance a regiment of very  magnificent maidens, as daringly arrayed as possible in t chorus costumes of the day.  The rest of this episode wil planned and staged later.  Its essence is that Kane is ju healthy and happy young man having a wonderful time. As some of the girls are detached from the line and made partners for individual dancing -

Dissolve just completes itself - the image of Kane dancin with a girl on each arm just disappears as camera pans do off the Temple Bldg. in the same action as the previous s scene.  There is a new sign on the side of the building b It reads:

head_text.subj: READ THE ENQUIRER GREATEST STAFF IN THE WORLD

text: Camera continues panning as we

A montage of various scenes, between the years 1891-1900. The scenes indicate the growth of the "Enquirer" under th impulse of Kane's personal drive.  Kane is shown, thus, a various activities: Move down from the sign: READ THE ENQUIRER  GREATEST STAF THE WORLD to street in front of saloon with parade passin (boys going off to the Spanish-American War)-  A torchlig parade with the torches reflected in the glass window of saloon - the sound of brass band playing "It's a Hot Time In the window of the saloon is a large sign or poster "RE

INSERT:  Remington drawing of American boys, similar to t parade above, in which "Our Boys" in the expeditionary ha are seen marching off to war. Back of observation car.  Shot of Kane congratulating Ted Roosevelt (the same shot as in the News Digest - without  flickering). The wooden floor of the railroad platform again - a bundl "Enquirers" - this time an enormous bundle - is thrown do and the moving shadows of the train behind the camera ind that it is going like a bat out of hell.  A reproduction Kane and Teddy shaking hands as above is very prominent i frame and almost hogs the entire front page.  The headlin indicates the surrender of Cuba.

Cartoon, highly dramatic and very involved as to content lousy with captions, labels, and symbolic figures, the mo gruesome and recognizable - "Capitalistic Greed."  This c is almost finished and is on a drawing board before which Kane and the artist himself.  Kane is grinning over some  suggestion he has made.

The cartoon finished and reproduced on the editorial page the "Enquirer" - in quite close, with an editorial and se faces of caps shown underneath.  The entire newspaper is with an angry gesture and thrown down into an expensive-l wastebasket (which is primarily for ticker tape) tape is  pouring.
Cartoonist and Kane working on comic strip of "Johnny the

Floor of room -  Two kids on floor, with newspaper spread looking at the same comic strip. Kane's photographic gallery with photographers, stooges, Kane himself in attendance on a very hot-looking item of period.  A sob sister is interviewing this hot number and is arranging her dress to look more seductive.

The hot number reproduced and prominently displayed and c almost half a page of the "Enquirer."  It is being read i barber shop and is seen in an over-shoulder shot of the m who is reading it.  He is getting a shine, a manicure, an haircut.  The sob-sister caption over the photograph reve

head_text.subj: "I DIDN'T KNOW WHAT I WAS DOING, SAYS DANCER. EVERYTHING

text: RED."  An oval photograph of the gun is included in the l out of the pretty lady with a headline which says: "DEATH
Shot of Kane, in evening clothes, in obvious position of grabbing camera from photographer.  Before him rages a te tenement fire.
INSERT:  Headline about inadequacy of present fire equipm
Final shot of a new horse-drawn steam engine roaring arou street corner (Stock).

A black pattern of iron bars.  We are in a prison cell. door is opened and a condemned man, with priest, warden a the usual attendants, moves into foreground and starts up hall past a group which includes phtographers, Kane's sob sister, and Kane.  The photographers take pictures with a flash of old-fashioned flash powder.  The condemned man i foreground (in silhouette) is startled by this.

A copy of the "Enquirer" spread out on a table.  A big la of the execution story includes the killer as photographe Kane's photographers, and nearby on the other page there large picture of the new steam fire engine (made from the shot) with a headline indicating that the "Enquirer" has its campaign for better equipment.  A cup of coffee and a doughnut are on the newspaper, and a servant girl - over shoulder we see the paper - is stirring the coffee. The Beaux Art Ball.  A number of elderly swells are jamme into a hallway.  Servants suddenly divest them of their f overcoats and wraps, revealing them to be in fancy dress  costume, pink fleshings, etc., the effect to be very surp very lavish and very very ridiculous.  We see, among othe Mr. Thatcher himself (as Ben Hur) ribbon around, his bald and all.  At the conclusion of this tableau, the image fr and we pull back to show it reproduced on the society pag the "New York Enquirer." Over the "Enquirer"'s pictorial version of the Beaux Art is thrown a huge fish - then coffee grounds - altogether pretty repulsive sight. The whole thing is bundled up and thrown into a garbage c Extreme close-up of the words: "OCCUPATION - JOUNALIST." Camera pulls back to show passport open to the photograph which shows Kane, registering birth, race, and nationalit Passport cover is closed, showing it to be an American pa

As camera pulls back over shoulder of official, taking in Leland, and Bernstein, we see the bustle and noise of dep ocean liner.  Behind the principles can be seen an enormo plain sign which reads: "FIRST CLASS."  From offstage can heard the steward's cry, indispensable in any Mercury  production, the old familiar cry, "All Ashore That's Goin Ashore!" - gongs, also blasts of the great whistle and al rest of it.
There you are, Mr. Kane.  Everything  in order.
Thank you.
Kane and Leland and Bernstein start up the gangplank.
(calling) Have a good rest, Mr. Kane.
Thanks.
But please, Mr. Kane, don't buy  any more paintings.  Nine Venuses  already we got, twenty-six Virgins -  two whole warehouses full of stuff -
I promise not to bring any more  Venuses and not to worry - and not  to try to get in touch with any of the papers -
All ashore!
- and to forget about the new  feature sections - and not to try  to think up and ideas for comic  sections.
All ashore that's going ashore!
Kane leaves Leland and Bernstein midway up gangplank, as rushes up to it, calling back with a wave:
Goodbye, gents! (at the top of the  gangplank, he turns  and calls down) Hey!
(calling down to  them) You don't expect me to keep any of  those promises, do you?
A band on deck strikes up "Auld Lang Syne."  Bernstein an Leland turn to each other.
Do you, Mr. Leland?
(smiling) Certainly not.
They start down the gangplank together.

The pattern of telegraph wires, dripping with rain, throu which we see the same old building but now rendered fairl remarkable by tremendous outline sign in gold which reads NEW YORK DAILY ENQUIRER."  A couple of lights show in the building.  We start toward the window where the lights sh as we -

location: OUTSIDE THE WINDOW AT BERNSTEIN'S DESK

text: The light in the window in the former shot was showing be the letter "E" of the Enquirer sign.  Now the letter "E" even larger than the frame of the camera.
